element.name: Sir William's Big Noodle by orangetigerprawn, Unknown Cache (4/2)

b.font: Sir William's Big Noodle Does Hard Sums

description.center:
In 1843, on a bright October day, William Rowan Hamilton,
the greatest Irish Mathematician of all time, discovered the numbers
called Quaternions.

long-description.center: For many years he had been trying to find a satisfactory way to multiply points in three dimensions, in such a way as to allow division. The idea of using four dimensions instead, and the way to do it, came to him in a flash, as he walked with his wife by the Royal Canal. Since it is one of the few major mathematical discoveries which is precisely located in time and circumstances, the event is very well-known in the international mathematical community, and people from all over the world know about "Hamilton's Bridge". When he made the discovery, Hamilton paused under Brougham (or Broom) Bridge, took out his penknife, and scratched the fundamental formula: i2 = j2 = k2 = ijk = -1 into the stone.
A plaque at the bridge reads:

Here as he walked by
Sir William Rowan Hamilton
in a flash of genius discovered
the fundamental formula for
quaternion multiplication
i² = j² = k² = ijk = -1
& cut it on a stone of this bridge.

Given the historical importance of the bridge with respect to mathematics, mathematicians from all over the world have been known to take part in the annual commemorative walk from Dunsink Observatory to the site. Attendees have included Nobel Prize winners Murray Gell-Mann, Steven Weinberg and Frank Wilczek, and mathematicians Sir Andrew Wiles and Ingrid Daubechies.
To find the cache you must do a bit of maths
It couldn't be that easy? Could it?
Of course it isn't. Those numbers are in red italics for a reason. Perhaps a bit more homework is on the cards.

ul.li:
2010-04-13T19:00:00Z : Found it by Fjon
Got a few big hints from the owner on the puzzle. To be honest I don't know if I would have ever figured it out myself. Dropped off at the location on the way home from work. Drive past here plenty of times, no idea there was something of interest in this area at all!

2010-03-30T19:00:00Z : Found it by Hezekiah
Scratched my head much more than was necessary over this one! Found easily once the penny dropped - TFTC!

2010-02-14T20:00:00Z : Found it by Windsockers
[green]Well my brain is noodled after this one it's times like these you realise you should have went to school [B)]
After a few days of head scratching moments, a formula was born and a likely set of numbers appeared.
A brief search at gz unearthed a pristeen log duly signed with a pen not knife [:P]
TfTc
please give the grey matter a rest [:P][:P][:P][:P][:P][:P][:P][:P][:P][:P][/green]

wpt.name: GC23VEV
wpt.desc: Sir William's Big Noodle by orangetigerprawn, Unknown Cache (4/2)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Sir William's Big Noodle
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:short_description:
Sir William's Big Noodle Does Hard Sums

 

In 1843, on a bright October day, William Rowan Hamilton,
the greatest Irish Mathematician of all time, discovered the numbers
called Quaternions.
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
For many years he had been trying to find a satisfactory way to multiply points in three dimensions, in such a way as to allow division. The idea of using four dimensions instead, and the way to do it, came to him in a flash, as he walked with his wife by the Royal Canal. Since it is one of the few major mathematical discoveries which is precisely located in time and circumstances, the event is very well-known in the international mathematical community, and people from all over the world know about "Hamilton's Bridge". When he made the discovery, Hamilton paused under Brougham (or Broom) Bridge, took out his penknife, and scratched the fundamental formula: i2 = j2 = k2 = ijk = -1 into the stone.

 

 

A plaque at the bridge reads:

Here as he walked by
Sir William Rowan Hamilton
in a flash of genius discovered
the fundamental formula for
quaternion multiplication
i² = j² = k² = ijk = -1
& cut it on a stone of this bridge.



Given the historical importance of the bridge with respect to mathematics, mathematicians from all over the world have been known to take part in the annual commemorative walk from Dunsink Observatory to the site. Attendees have included Nobel Prize winners Murray Gell-Mann, Steven Weinberg and Frank Wilczek, and mathematicians Sir Andrew Wiles and Ingrid Daubechies.

 

 

The Cache
To find the cache you must do a bit of maths
N 53° 22.(2*6+1)*6+2 W 006° 17.(2*6*8-6*8+7)*6-3+4
 
It couldn't be that easy? Could it?
Of course it isn't. Those numbers are in red italics for a reason. Perhaps a bit more homework is on the cards.

Additional Waypoints

groundspeak:log.groundspeak:text: Got a few big hints from the owner on the puzzle. To be honest I don't know if I would have ever figured it out myself. Dropped off at the location on the way home from work. Drive past here plenty of times, no idea there was something of interest in this area at all!
Scratched my head much more than was necessary over this one! Found easily once the penny dropped - TFTC!

[green]Well my brain is noodled after this one it's times like these you realise you should have went to school [B)]
After a few days of head scratching moments, a formula was born and a likely set of numbers appeared.
A brief search at gz unearthed a pristeen log duly signed with a pen not knife [:P]
TfTc
